sentences.english: Unfortunately, he was dubbed the "full back that never returns" by some sections of utd fans.
sentences.chinese: 他还被某些曼联球迷戏称为“不回家的左后卫”。

sentences.english: Last week we called this a Congressional comb-over.
sentences.chinese: 上周我们曾戏称国会此举无异于拆东墙补西墙。

sentences.english: The Chinese media have dubbed her "the stubborn nail" for her refusal to give up.
sentences.chinese: 中国媒体将她拒绝让步的行为戏称为“钉子户”。

sentences.english: “Suit” was the chosen insult of hippies to describe a dull establishment man.
sentences.chinese: 西服曾被嬉皮士戏称为乏味的人的衣着标志。

sentences.english: We often jokingly call him “Prime Minister”.
sentences.chinese: 我们经常戏称德闽是总理。

sentences.english: " The alien was produced as a slip-on mask, and nicknamed "Goggle-Eyes" by the crew.
sentences.chinese: 这个外星人的道具是套头面具，剧组戏称“水泡眼”。

sentences.english: Customs officers call it a " cat and mouse game".
sentences.chinese: 海关工作人员戏称为“一场猫和老鼠的博弈”。

sentences.english: Many Egyptians scornfully call Mr. Mubarak “the Pharaoh.”
sentences.chinese: 许多埃及人把穆巴拉克戏称为“暴君法老王”。

sentences.english: It was nicknamed the “pushbutton car” because of its push button feature.
sentences.chinese: 迅雷因为它的按键功能被戏称为“按键车”。

sentences.english: They have been jokingly Palace chief as "husband", called Shun of the mouth.
sentences.chinese: 她们一直戏称宫科长为“老公”，叫顺了口。

sentences.english: Brown was making jokes about his big clunking fist in Birmingham.
sentences.chinese: 在伯明翰，布朗戏称他的拳头巨大而沉重。

sentences.english: All the 09 grads can be mocked for being an unlucky bunch.
sentences.chinese: 09级毕业生们被戏称为不幸的一群人。

sentences.english: Well, this is what is laughingly known as my apartment.
sentences.chinese: 好的，这就是被戏称为我的公寓的地方。

sentences.english: People called it as “The Big Pant ”.
sentences.chinese: 老百姓戏称它是“大裤衩”。

sentences.english: I did it and got something called "Sloppy Sardines.
sentences.chinese: 我试着做了并且戏称这种配方为“草率的沙丁鱼”。

sentences.english: Many Imperial officers nicknamed the planet "Moneylend."
sentences.chinese: 许多帝国官员把缪尼林斯特戏称为“贷款星”。

definition: called/to call sth (by a name)/to name
to be called/to be known as
person (first person, second person etc in grammar)/called/known as
to be known as/to be nicknamed/to be purportedly/to claim (often exaggeratedly or falsely)
not just in name only, but also in reality (idiom)
